study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether milk thistle could serve as an effective hepatoprotective agent in a patient with chemotherapy-induced transaminitis.
results_summary: The study found that milk thistle led to an immediate decrease in liver function tests and reduced elevation in levels during subsequent chemotherapy regimens, suggesting potential efficacy as a hepatoprotective agent.
population_specificity: A single patient with chemotherapy-induced transaminitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of silymarin (from Milk Thistle) in mitigating ethanol-induced oxidative stress, immune dysfunction, and vascular impairment in mice.
results_summary: Silymarin significantly normalized ethanol-induced oxidative stress markers (e.g., TBARS, nitrite, GSH, SOD, CAT) and modulated immune cytokines (e.g., IL-10, TNF-α, IFN-γ, VEGF-A, TGF-β1), with effects comparable to ascorbic acid.
population_specificity: 8- to 10-week-old male BALB/c mice (20-30 g).
effective_dosage: 250 mg/kg body weight of silymarin (silybin) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of Milk Thistle (silymarin) in treating various liver diseases and its mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Silymarin demonstrated antioxidant, antifibrotic, and toxin-blocking properties, reducing liver injury from multiple causes in animals and showing potential in treating alcoholic liver disease, viral hepatitis, and toxin-induced liver diseases.
population_specificity: Animals and general human applications (alcoholic liver disease, viral hepatitis, toxin-induced liver diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the photoprotective potential of silymarin (from Milk Thistle) against UV radiation-induced skin damage and photocarcinogenesis.
results_summary: Silymarin demonstrated significant anti-carcinogenic effects in mouse models, reducing tumor incidence, multiplicity, and growth through antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and immunomodulatory mechanisms. It may supplement sunscreen protection and mitigate UV-induced skin damage.
population_specificity: Mouse models (not human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (topical treatment mentioned, but exact dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and potential carcinogenic activity of milk thistle extract in rats and mice over short-term (3-month) and long-term (2-year) exposure periods.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of carcinogenic activity in rats or mice exposed to milk thistle extract. It noted decreased incidences of certain neoplasms in female rats and male mice but also observed increased liver foci in female rats and reduced body weights in mice at higher doses.
population_specificity: Male and female F344/N rats and B6C3F1 mice.
effective_dosage: Varied by study (e.g., 3,125–50,000 ppm in feed, equivalent to 260–11,620 mg/kg body weight daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety and efficacy of Milk Thistle in reducing chemotherapy-associated hepatotoxicity in children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in side effects or toxicities between the Milk Thistle and placebo groups. At Day 56, the Milk Thistle group showed a significantly lower AST and a trend toward lower ALT, suggesting a potential reduction in liver toxicity.
population_specificity: Children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and hepatic toxicity.
interactions: No antagonistic interactions with vincristine or L-asparaginase; a modest synergistic effect with vincristine was observed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if milk thistle (silymarin) provides hepatoprotective effects against acute B1 aflatoxin exposure in pigeons.
results_summary: The study found no significant hepatoprotective effects of milk thistle against aflatoxin-induced liver damage in pigeons, except for minor reductions in some enzyme levels at the 10 mg/kg dosage.
population_specificity: White Carneaux pigeons (Columba livia)
effective_dosage: 0, 10, or 100 mg/kg body weight per day
study_duration: Not specified (after acclimation, birds were challenged with aflatoxin for 2 consecutive days)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of silymarin and its flavonolignans in inhibiting oxidized LDL generation and monocyte adherence to oxLDL.
results_summary: Silymarin and its components (SC, SD, SBN, IS) significantly reduced oxLDL generation by 28.1-60.0%. SBN also showed dose-dependent inhibition of monocyte adhesion, likely due to antioxidant and free radical scavenging mechanisms.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cellular targets responsible for silymarin's inhibition of UV-induced oxidative stress in mouse skin.
results_summary: Silymarin significantly reduced UV-induced oxidative stress by inhibiting infiltrating CD11b+ cells, decreasing leukocyte infiltration, and lowering ROS/H2O2 production in both epidermal and dermal cells. Its effects were comparable to anti-CD11b monoclonal antibody treatment.
population_specificity: C3H/HeN mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective and therapeutic effects of an herbal extract mixture (including Milk Thistle) and yogurt on ethanol-induced liver injury.
results_summary: The herbal extract mixture and yogurt provided protection against ethanol-induced liver toxicity comparable to commercial drugs, reduced liver injury, and lowered lipid deposition. Co-treatment with the herbal extract and yogurt also protected against repeated ethanol exposure.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal model implied by dosage in g/kg body weight).
effective_dosage: Single oral dose of ethanol (3 g/kg body weight); triple oral dose (2 g/kg body weight over one week). Herbal extract and yogurt dosages not specified.
study_duration: Initial treatment for two weeks, extended for three more weeks (total five weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the beneficial and harmful effects of milk thistle or its constituents versus placebo or no intervention in patients with alcoholic liver disease and/or viral liver diseases (hepatitis B and C).
results_summary: Milk thistle showed no significant effect on mortality, complications of liver disease, or liver histology. While liver-related mortality was reduced in all trials, this effect was not observed in high-quality trials, and milk thistle was not associated with increased adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with alcoholic liver disease and/or hepatitis B or C virus liver diseases (acute and chronic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether silibinin or silipide consumption affects breast cancer development in a transgenic mouse model of mammary adenocarcinoma.
results_summary: The study found that neither silibinin nor silipide promoted or interfered with tumor development in the mouse model, suggesting that promotion of carcinogenesis is not a consistent feature of silibinin across rodent models of mammary carcinogenesis.
population_specificity: C3(1) SV40 T,t antigen transgenic multiple mammary adenocarcinoma mice
study_duration: From weaning until the end of the experiment (duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent clinical trials on milk thistle, focusing on its safety, pharmacokinetics, herb-drug interactions, and efficacy in treating liver diseases, cancer, hepatitis C, HIV, diabetes, and hypercholesterolemia.
results_summary: The study found that milk thistle extracts are safe and well-tolerated, with minimal adverse effects. Promising results were reported for its protective effects in certain cancers and liver diseases, though more high-quality trials are needed to confirm efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with liver diseases, cancer, hepatitis C, HIV, diabetes, and hypercholesterolemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a method for quantifying silibinin in human plasma and assess its presence in colorectal cancer patients after treatment.
results_summary: The study developed a reliable HPLC method for detecting silibinin in plasma, achieving linear detection over 0-5000 ng/mL. Silibinin was detected in colorectal patients after 7 days of treatment with silipide.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the nomenclature and composition of milk thistle extracts and evaluate their potential in cancer therapeutics, including chemoprevention, treatment, and mitigating chemotherapy side effects.
results_summary: Milk thistle extracts, particularly silymarin and silibinin, show promise in preventing hepatotoxicity and synergizing with chemotherapeutics, with low drug-interaction potential. However, high-dose phase II studies require caution.
population_specificity: Not specified (preclinical and clinical studies referenced generally).
interactions: Low drug-interaction potential, but synergizes with some chemotherapeutics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hepatoprotective effects of silymarin (derived from milk thistle) on ethanol-induced oxidative damage in rats, comparing its efficacy to ascorbic acid and assessing hepatic regeneration during abstention.
results_summary: Silymarin reversed ethanol-induced oxidative damage by reducing TBARS levels and restoring antioxidant enzyme activities (SOD, GST, GSH, catalase, GR, GPx), though its hepatoprotective effect was less pronounced than ascorbic acid. Abstinence from ethanol also contributed to hepatic regeneration.
population_specificity: Male albino rats (Wistar strain, 16-18 weeks old, weighing 200-220 g) exposed to ethanol.
effective_dosage: Ethanol dose: 1.6 g/kg body weight/day; silymarin dosage not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the beneficial and harmful effects of milk thistle or its constituents versus placebo or no intervention in patients with alcoholic liver disease and/or hepatitis B and/or C liver diseases.
results_summary: Milk thistle showed no significant effects on all-cause mortality, complications of liver disease, or liver histology. While liver-related mortality was reduced in all trials, this effect was not observed in high-quality trials, and no significant increase in adverse events was noted.
population_specificity: Patients with alcoholic liver disease and/or hepatitis B or C liver diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and potential applications of Milk Thistle in treating liver disease, cancer, and Amanita phalloides poisoning.
results_summary: The study found that Milk Thistle appears safe with rare serious side effects, but clinical evidence on efficacy is heterogeneous and contradictory. Ongoing studies may clarify its effectiveness in oncology and infectious disease.
population_specificity: Not specified (general use implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential use of Milk Thistle (Silybum marianum) and its derivatives for treating alcoholic liver disease based on published literature.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that Milk Thistle appears safe and has promising mechanisms of action, but insufficient data from well-conducted clinical trials exist to recommend its use for alcoholic liver disease due to variability in study quality and inconsistent outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with alcoholic liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the beneficial and harmful effects of milk thistle or its constituents versus placebo or no intervention in patients with alcoholic liver disease and/or viral liver diseases (hepatitis B and C).
results_summary: Milk thistle showed no significant effect on overall mortality, complications of liver disease, or liver histology. While liver-related mortality was reduced in all trials, this effect was not observed in high-quality trials, and no significant increase in adverse events was reported.
population_specificity: Patients with alcoholic liver disease and/or hepatitis B or C virus liver diseases (acute and chronic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer effects of isolated flavonolignan compounds from milk thistle, particularly their antiproliferative activities against human prostate carcinoma cell lines.
results_summary: Isosilybin B was the most potent suppressor of prostate cancer cell growth and prostate-specific antigen secretion, outperforming other compounds and commercial extracts. Silymarin and silibinin also suppressed DNA topoisomerase IIα gene promoter activity, with isosilybin B being the most effective.
population_specificity: Human prostate carcinoma cell lines (LNCaP, DU145, PC3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if milk thistle (silymarin) affects the pharmacokinetics of indinavir.
results_summary: The study found no apparent effect of silymarin on indinavir plasma concentrations, as the pharmacokinetic parameters remained similar when indinavir was given alone or combined with silymarin.
population_specificity: Ten healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the extraction efficiency of silymarins from whole and defatted milk thistle seeds using different solvents and temperatures.
results_summary: The study found that ethanol at 60°C yielded the highest quantities of silymarins, while boiling water was effective for extracting more polar silymarins like taxifolin and silychristin. Defatted seed meal extracted with boiling ethanol produced the highest yields of specific silymarins, with some compounds showing significantly higher yields compared to whole seeds.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Milk Thistle could prevent or treat liver dysfunction in patients undergoing anticancer therapy.
results_summary: The abstract suggests Milk Thistle may be useful for liver dysfunction in cancer patients but does not provide specific efficacy data or outcomes. No concrete results are detailed regarding its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing anticancer therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and safety of milk thistle for treating chronic liver disease through a systematic review of randomized placebo-controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in mortality, improvements in liver histology, or meaningful changes in biochemical markers of liver function with milk thistle. Adverse effects were rare and comparable to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether milk thistle affects the pharmacokinetics of indinavir and the duration of any potential interaction.
results_summary: Milk thistle did not significantly alter overall indinavir exposure (9% reduction in AUC8), but it decreased trough levels (C8) by 25%. The study concluded that milk thistle should not interfere with indinavir therapy in HIV patients.
population_specificity: Ten healthy volunteers.
effective_dosage: 175 mg milk thistle (containing 153 mg silymarin) three times daily.
interactions: Interaction with indinavir was studied, but no significant interference was found.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and potential benefits of milk thistle (silymarin) for liver disease, particularly its hepatoprotective, anti-inflammatory, and regenerative properties.
results_summary: Small studies suggest silymarin has beneficial effects for some types of hepatitis, but its potential interference with interferon or ribavirin remains unclear. A larger, well-designed study is underway to further investigate its efficacy in hepatitis C.
population_specificity: Patients with liver disease, particularly hepatitis.
interactions: Potential interference with interferon or ribavirin mentioned, but unclear.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of silymarin (a component of Milk Thistle) on hepatic drug-metabolizing enzymes in human hepatocyte cultures.
results_summary: Silymarin significantly reduced the activity of CYP3A4 and UGT1A6/9 enzymes and decreased mitochondrial respiration in human hepatocytes, suggesting potential impairment of hepatic metabolism for coadministered drugs.
population_specificity: Human hepatocyte cultures
interactions: Potential impairment of hepatic metabolism of certain coadministered drugs, possibly increasing toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the cancer chemopreventive and anti-carcinogenic effects of silymarin (from milk thistle) are primarily due to its major component, silibinin.
results_summary: Silibinin significantly inhibited cell growth and DNA synthesis in prostate, breast, and cervical carcinoma cells, with comparable effects to silymarin, suggesting silibinin is the primary active component responsible for these effects.
population_specificity: Human prostate, breast, and cervical carcinoma cells (in vitro).
study_duration: Time-dependent effects observed, but exact duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review silymarin's history, pharmacology, properties, and clinical trials related to its effects on acute and chronic liver disease.
results_summary: The study found that silymarin and its active constituent, silybin, exhibit antioxidant properties, protect against genomic injury, enhance hepatocyte protein synthesis, and may inhibit tumor promoters. Clinical trials suggest potential benefits for liver disease patients.
population_specificity: Patients with acute and chronic liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between adherence to the MIND diet and the likelihood of postpartum depressive symptoms in women.
results_summary: The study found that higher adherence to the MIND diet was significantly associated with lower postpartum depressive symptom scores and a reduced likelihood of experiencing these symptoms. The adjusted model showed a strong inverse relationship (OR: 0.04, 95% CI: 0.006-0.37; P < 0.001).
population_specificity: 214 women (2-8 weeks postpartum) referred to comprehensive health service centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify plasma proteins associated with the MIND diet score and assess their ability to predict incident dementia.
results_summary: The study identified 62 proteins linked to the MIND diet, with 21 improving diet score prediction. Five proteins were significantly associated with dementia risk, improving prediction beyond known risk factors.
population_specificity: 10,230 Black and White participants from the Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between the MIND diet, chronotype, and lifestyle factors in overweight and obese individuals.
results_summary: The study found an inverse association between MIND diet score and BMI/waist circumference, with higher compliance linked to lower CRP levels. Morning chronotype participants showed better adherence to the MIND diet and healthier food choices.
population_specificity: 1100 obese individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between adherence to the MIND diet, physical functionality, and cognitive impairment among elderly individuals in Pakistan.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was significantly associated with reduced cognitive impairment (odds ratio 0.29). The study also found that lower physical activity levels correlated with increased cognitive impairment.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged 65 and above in Pakistan.
study_duration: Cross-sectional study conducted from January to June 2023 (no specific intervention duration mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of the MIND diet on anthropometric measurements, sleep quality, depression, anxiety, and serum levels of cortisol and BDNF in type 2 diabetic women with insomnia.
results_summary: The MIND diet significantly reduced waist circumference, improved sleep quality, depression, and anxiety, lowered cortisol levels, and increased BDNF compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 44 type 2 diabetic women with insomnia, aged 30 to 65 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (low-calorie MIND diet vs. low-calorie diet as control).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between adherence to the MIND diet and its components with recurrent depressive symptoms in a British cohort.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with a 26% lower odds of recurrent depressive symptoms, with green leafy vegetables, other vegetables, and berries showing independent protective effects.
population_specificity: 4824 participants (73% men, mean age 61) from the British Whitehall II cohort study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between adherence to the MIND diet and metabolic health status in Iranian adolescents with overweight/obesity.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with lower odds of metabolically unhealthy overweight/obesity (MUO), hyperglycemia, and insulin resistance, particularly among girls and individuals with overweight.
population_specificity: Iranian adolescents (12-18 years) with overweight/obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess caregivers' capabilities, opportunities, and motivation to follow the MIND diet using the COM-B model approach.
results_summary: Most caregivers were not consuming the MIND diet, with only 8.4% reporting adherence. Barriers included budget, time, and transportation, while facilitators included budget planning, cooking skills, and family support.
population_specificity: Female caregivers (n = 299, mean age = 37.7 ± 13.7), predominantly White (72%), caring for someone with Alzheimer's disease (42.6%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of the MIND diet on mental health, PCOS-related quality of life, anthropometric indices, hirsutism, and metabolic/hormonal parameters in women with PCOS.
results_summary: The MIND diet significantly reduced depression and anxiety scores and improved emotion and body hair domains of PCOSQ compared to the control group, though other parameters did not show significant differences. Both groups showed weight and BMI improvements, with a slight advantage for the MIND diet group.
population_specificity: 52 women with PCOS, aged 18-45 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between the MIND diet and cognitive decline in older adults, specifically comparing outcomes between Black and White participants.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with slower cognitive decline in both Black and White older adults, though the association was stronger and more consistent among White participants. The effect was attenuated for Black participants when accounting for vascular and lifestyle factors.
population_specificity: 5,259 older adults (73.5 ± 6.0 years, 62% Black, 62% female) from the Chicago Health and Aging Project.
effective_dosage: Not specified (MIND diet score range: 0-15, with tertiles analyzed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of the MIND diet on clinical and biochemical outcomes in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients.
results_summary: The study found that the MIND diet improved fatigue scores and physical quality-of-life in MS patients, along with reductions in oxidative stress markers like lipoperoxidation and 8-hydroxy-2'-deoxyguanosine. Significant differences were also observed in serum BDNF and glutathione levels compared to healthy controls.
population_specificity: Multiple sclerosis (MS) patients and healthy control subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify molecular mechanisms linking the MIND diet to cognitive health by examining its correlation with brain transcriptomic profiles and dementia risk.
results_summary: The study found a transcriptomic profile (50 genes) correlated with the MIND diet, associated with slower cognitive decline and lower dementia odds. Specific genes (e.g., TCIM, IGSF5) appeared to mediate this association.
population_specificity: 1204 older adults from the Religious Orders Study and Memory and Aging Project, with post mortem prefrontal cortex tissue analysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to conduct a bibliometric analysis of the MIND diet to identify leading research trends and hotspots, providing a reference for future studies.
results_summary: The study found that the MIND diet shows neuroprotective potential, with even moderate adherence linked to reduced Alzheimer's risk and slower cognitive decline. It also suggests possible benefits for other health outcomes like CVDs, cancer, and diabetes, though current evidence is limited.
population_specificity: Global research contributions from 953 authors across 362 institutions in 37 countries/regions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an updated and comprehensive overview of human studies examining the MIND diet's association with brain aging outcomes in adults aged 40 years and older.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was protective against dementia in 7 of 10 cohorts and showed positive associations with global cognition (3 of 4 cohorts) and episodic memory (4 of 6 cohorts). However, evidence for cognitive decline and other brain outcomes was mixed or limited.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥40 years, primarily North American cohorts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adherence to the MIND diet was associated with reduced odds of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and changes in inflammatory biomarkers (hsCRP, IL-6) over three years in adults aged 70+.
results_summary: The study found no association between MIND diet adherence and cognitive decline or changes in inflammatory biomarkers (hsCRP, IL-6) over three years. Sensitivity analyses confirmed these findings.
population_specificity: Adults aged 70+ (mean age 74.88 years; 60.5% women) from the DO-HEALTH study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the MIND diet's potential for preventing and/or treating dementia across various dementia pathologies.
results_summary: The studies reviewed found a positive correlation between MIND diet adherence and cognitive functioning, though results were mixed for specific cognitive domains. The diet showed promise as a long-term treatment option, but more research is needed on subjects with onset dementias and underlying mechanisms.
population_specificity: Individuals 65+ with mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer's disease, general dementia, or significant risk factors for dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adherence to the MIND diet influences selenium intake and concentrations, potentially explaining its neuroprotective benefits.
results_summary: Greater MIND diet adherence was associated with higher dietary selenium intake and urinary excretion but lower serum selenium levels, including potentially neurotoxic forms like selenoprotein P and selenate, suggesting a protective mechanism against cognitive decline.
population_specificity: 137 non-smoking blood donors (75 females, 62 males) from Reggio Emilia, Northern Italy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of the MIND diet to provide protection against cardiometabolic diseases and associated risk factors in adults.
results_summary: The MIND diet was generally associated with improvements in anthropometric measures and cardiometabolic outcomes like blood pressure, glycemic control, lipid profile, inflammation, and stroke, though effects on some cardiovascular diseases were less conclusive.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the cognitive benefits of a modified Korean MIND (K-MIND) diet and explore associated biomarkers using multi-omics analysis.
results_summary: The K-MIND diet significantly improved "orientation to place" in cognitive tests and upregulated genes linked to mitochondrial respiration and immune processes while downregulating inflammatory responses. It also affected metabolic pathways tied to neurotransmitter synthesis and brain cell membrane structure.
population_specificity: Elderly Korean population

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the MIND Diet is correlated with a specific cortical gene expression profile and whether this profile is associated with dementia risk.
results_summary: The study identified a transcriptomic profile of 50 genes linked to the MIND Diet, which was associated with slower cognitive decline and lower dementia odds. Several genes, including TCIM, appeared to mediate the diet's protective effects.
population_specificity: Deceased participants from the Religious Orders Study (ROS) and Rush Memory and Aging Project (MAP), with postmortem brain tissue analysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the impact of adhering to the MIND diet on all-cause and cardiovascular mortality in patients with and without type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found that a high MIND diet score (>8.0) was associated with significantly lower risks of all-cause and cardiovascular death in patients with T2DM, and a lower risk of all-cause death in those without T2DM, though the association with cardiovascular death in non-T2DM participants was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 6,887 participants (1,021 with T2DM) from the NHANES dataset.
effective_dosage: Not specified (adherence measured by MIND diet score, range 4.5-13).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether adherence to the MIND diet is associated with the odds and severity of anxiety disorders (AD).
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with lower anxiety severity (GAD-7 score) and a 97% reduced likelihood of having AD. A significant inverse linear relationship was found between MIND diet score and AD.
population_specificity: 85 patients with anxiety disorders and 170 healthy subjects, group-matched by gender.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between adherence to the MIND diet and its effects on general obesity and blood lipid profile.
results_summary: Greater adherence to the MIND diet was associated with a 42% lower chance of increased serum triglycerides and reduced odds of general obesity and unfavorable lipid profiles. The effects remained significant after adjusting for confounders.
population_specificity: 1,328 Kurdish adults aged 39-53 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association of the MIND diet with cognitive function and its decline among middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with better global cognitive function and potentially slower cognitive decline, with specific positive associations for nuts, fish, red meats, and tea, and negative associations for fried foods. The meta-analysis confirmed these findings across multiple studies.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults from the China Health and Nutrition Survey.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between adherence to the MIND diet and metabolically unhealthy overweight/obesity (MUHOW/O) phenotypes in women.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between MIND diet adherence and MUH phenotypes, though a marginal downward trend in MUH odds was observed with higher MIND diet tertiles. The trend became statistically significant after adjusting for marital status.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese women (BMI ≥ 25 kg/m²) aged 18-48 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (MIND diet score based on 15 components via FFQ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between the MIND diet, mental health, and metabolic markers in individuals with obesity.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with lower stress levels, higher insulin sensitivity, and increased intake of brain-healthy foods, but no significant changes in other metabolic parameters.
population_specificity: 339 individuals with obesity (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m²) aged 20-50 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between adherence to the MIND diet and the risk of breast cancer in Tehranian adult women.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with a 45% lower risk of breast cancer, particularly among women with a history of abortion. The association remained significant after adjusting for confounding variables.
population_specificity: Tehranian women aged ≥30 years, including 134 with recently diagnosed breast cancer and 272 age-matched controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether better adherence to the MIND diet was associated with improved outcomes, specifically reduced all-cause and cardiovascular mortality, in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) or stroke.
results_summary: The study found that higher adherence to the MIND diet was significantly associated with lower risks of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality in ASCVD patients, with hazard ratios showing a dose-response relationship. Each one-score increase in MIND diet adherence was linked to a 10% lower risk of all-cause mortality and a 16% lower risk of cardiovascular mortality.
population_specificity: 943 patients with ASCVD or stroke from the NHANES 2003-2006 cohort.
effective_dosage: Not specified (diet adherence scored as ≤7.0, 7.5-8.0, and ≥8.5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association of a French-adapted MIND diet score with gray matter volumes, white matter microstructure, and incident dementia in older adults.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the French MIND diet was associated with a lower risk of dementia and Alzheimer's disease, as well as preserved white matter microstructure, though no significant association was found with gray matter volumes.
population_specificity: French older adults (≥65 years) from the Three-City Bordeaux cohort.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary score range 0-15 based on food frequency questionnaire and 24-hour recall).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of a calorie-restricted MIND diet on cognitive performance and brain structure changes in healthy obese women.
results_summary: The MIND diet group showed significant improvements in working memory, verbal recognition memory, and attention compared to the control group, along with increased surface area in the inferior frontal gyrus and greater reductions in cerebellum-white matter and cerebellum-cortex volumes.
population_specificity: Healthy obese women (mean BMI 32 ± 4.31 kg/m², mean age 48 ± 5.38 years).
effective_dosage: Calorie-restricted modified MIND diet (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of the MIND diet on anthropometric parameters, hunger hormones, and brain structures in overweight and obese women.
results_summary: The MIND diet group showed significant improvements in weight, BMI, body fat percentage, waist circumference, and leptin levels, along with increased ghrelin and GLP-1 levels, but no changes in brain structures were observed.
population_specificity: 37 healthy overweight and obese women with a mean age of 48±5.38 years and BMI of 32±0.69 Kg/m2.
effective_dosage: Hypocaloric modified MIND diet (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between adherence to the MIND diet and psychological disorders (depression, anxiety, and stress) in an Iranian adult population.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was significantly associated with lower odds of depression and anxiety, but not psychological stress, after adjusting for multiple confounders.
population_specificity: 7,165 Iranian adults from the Yazd Health Study (YaHS) and Yazd Nutrition Study (TAMYZ).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary intake assessed via FFQ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between adherence to the MIND diet and cognitive performance in a Brazilian population, particularly examining the modifying effect of income.
results_summary: MIND diet adherence was not associated with cognition in the overall sample. However, income modified the effect: high-income participants showed better executive function with greater adherence, while low-income participants showed lower global cognition and executive function with greater adherence.
population_specificity: 11,788 participants from the Brazilian Longitudinal Study of Adult Health (ELSA-Brasil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between adherence to the MIND diet and the risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) in adults over a 10.6-year period.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with a 16% reduction in CVD incidence, with specific components like whole grains, green leafy vegetables, and beans showing significant risk reductions (60%, 45%, and 65%, respectively). The study found an inverse relationship between MIND diet adherence and CVD events.
population_specificity: 2863 adults free of CVD at baseline, followed for 10.6 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (adherence measured via food frequency questionnaire).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between long-term adherence to the MIND diet and cognitive function over 8 years, and whether socioeconomic factors influenced this relationship.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with better cognitive function at baseline and over 8 years, but not with cognitive trajectory. Socioeconomic factors like education, income, and job complexity acted as confounders but did not modify the diet-cognition relationship.
population_specificity: Puerto Rican adults aged 45-75 residing in the Boston, MA area.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the interactions between CAV1 polymorphism and the MIND diet on metabolic dyslipidemia in overweight and obese patients.
results_summary: The study found a significant interaction between the MIND diet and CAV1 rs3807992, where subjects with dominant alleles had a lower risk of dyslipidemia. Higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with reduced dyslipidemia in risk allele carriers.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between adherence to the MIND diet and the risk of dementia, addressing potential reverse causality and residual confounding by lifestyle factors.
results_summary: Higher MIND diet scores were associated with a lower risk of dementia in the short term (7 years), but associations weakened over longer follow-up periods. The association was stronger in more contemporary dietary data compared to historical data.
population_specificity: 5375 participants from the Rotterdam Study (1989-1993) and 2861 participants from a later cohort (2009-2013).
study_duration: Mean follow-up of 15.6 years (baseline I) and 5.9 years (baseline II).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between adherence to the MIND diet and the risk of breast cancer among Iranian women.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between the MIND diet score and the odds of breast cancer, either before or after adjusting for potential confounders, in both pre-menopausal and post-menopausal women.
population_specificity: Iranian women (150 newly diagnosed breast cancer cases and 150 age-matched controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the validity of the cognitive battery used in the MIND Diet Intervention to measure cognitive decline and brain atrophy in older adults at risk for Alzheimer's dementia.
results_summary: The study found that the MIND cognitive battery effectively measured four distinct cognitive domains (executive function, perceptual speed, episodic memory, and semantic memory) and showed expected associations with age, education, and cognitive activity. The results support the battery's validity for use in diet intervention trials.
population_specificity: Older adults (average age 70 years) at risk for Alzheimer's dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between adherence to the MIND diet and the odds of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) among Iranian adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between adherence to the MIND diet and the odds of IBS, including when analyzed by gender, BMI status, or IBS subtypes.
population_specificity: 3,362 Iranian adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and compare factors influencing dietary behavior changes toward the MIND diet in 40-55-year-olds in Northern Ireland and Italy to reduce cognitive decline risk.
results_summary: The study found barriers like time, work environment, taste preference, and convenience, while facilitators included improved health, memory, and access to quality food. Cross-cultural differences in psychosocial factors were noted, with more barriers than facilitators reported.
population_specificity: 40-55-year-old males and females from Northern Ireland and Italy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between adherence to the MIND diet and metabolic syndrome (MetS), general obesity, and abdominal obesity in Iranian adults.
results_summary: The study found a non-significant 12% lower odds of MetS with higher MIND diet adherence but a significant inverse association with reduced HDL-C and general obesity after adjusting for confounders.
population_specificity: 836 Iranian adults aged 18-75 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adherence to the MIND diet is associated with a reduced risk of breast cancer in women.
results_summary: The study found that higher adherence to the MIND diet was associated with significantly lower odds of breast cancer, particularly in postmenopausal and normal-weight women, with odds reductions of 50-60% compared to low adherence.
population_specificity: Women aged ≥30 years residing in Isfahan, Iran, including 350 newly diagnosed breast cancer patients and 700 age-matched healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors influencing dietary behavior modification to adopt the MIND diet among middle-aged adults in the UK, focusing on barriers and facilitators.
results_summary: The study found that time, work environment, taste preference, and convenience were key barriers to adopting the MIND diet, while improved health, memory, planning, and access to quality food were facilitators. More barriers than facilitators were reported.
population_specificity: Men and women aged 40-55 years living in Northern Ireland.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association of the MIND diet, a Mediterranean-type diet, and a traditional diet with all-cause mortality over a 12-year period in an older population.
results_summary: The MIND diet was inversely associated with all-cause mortality, reducing the risk of death by 12% per unit increase in MIND diet score and by 37% for those in the top third of adherence. No significant associations were found for the Mediterranean-type or traditional diets in the final model.
population_specificity: 882 participants from the Lothian Birth Cohort 1936, mean age 69.5 years, in Edinburgh, Scotland.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine if the MIND diet is effective in preventing cognitive decline after stroke.
results_summary: High adherence to the MIND diet was associated with a slower rate of global cognitive decline over an average of 5.9 years of follow-up, even after adjusting for confounders. The top tertile of MIND diet scores showed a statistically significant slower decline compared to the lowest tertile.
population_specificity: 106 participants from a community cohort study with a clinical history of stroke.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary components included whole grains, leafy greens, berries, beans, nuts, lean meats, fish, poultry, olive oil, and reduced intake of cheese, butter, fried foods, and sweets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adherence to the MIND diet was associated with subjective memory complaints (SMC) in older adults.
results_summary: The MIND diet was not significantly associated with SMC in the full sample or participants aged 60-69, but a significant inverse association was observed in those aged ≥70, particularly after excluding participants with depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: 6,011 participants aged ≥60 years without SMC at baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effects of the MIND diet on cognitive function in individuals at risk for Alzheimer's dementia (AD).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study is designed to assess cognitive function, brain structure, and volume changes through MRI scans and other measurements over a 3-year period.
population_specificity: Men and women aged 65 to 84 years at risk for AD.
effective_dosage: Not specified (foods like extra-virgin olive oil, blueberries, and nuts were provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the MIND Diet is associated with reduced risk and slower progression of parkinsonism in older adults.
results_summary: Higher MIND diet scores were associated with a decreased risk of parkinsonism and slower progression, while the Mediterranean diet showed marginal benefits and the DASH diet showed no association.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 59-97 years without parkinsonism at baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between adherence to the MIND diet and the Mediterranean diet with the risk of incident depression.
results_summary: The study found no association between the MIND diet and reduced depression risk, while the Mediterranean diet showed a statistically significant reduction in depression risk. Specific dietary components like fruits, nuts, and avoidance of fast/fried food were linked to lower depression risk.
population_specificity: 15,980 adults initially free of depression at baseline or in the first 2 years of follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the MIND diet, designed to capture neuroprotective dietary components, was associated with slower cognitive decline over time.
results_summary: The MIND diet score was positively associated with slower decline in global cognitive function and across five cognitive domains, with the top tertile of adherence equivalent to being 7.5 years younger in cognitive age. The findings suggest the MIND diet substantially slows cognitive decline.
population_specificity: 960 participants from the Memory and Aging Project.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between adherence to the MIND diet and cognitive function/decline, including potential interactions with the apolipoprotein E ε4 genotype.
results_summary: Greater long-term adherence to the MIND diet was associated with better verbal memory but not with cognitive decline over six years in global cognition, verbal memory, or TICS.
population_specificity: 16,058 older women aged 70 and over from the Nurses' Health Study.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary intake assessed via Food Frequency Questionnaire).
study_duration: Dietary intake assessed five times between 1984 and 1998; cognitive assessments conducted from 1995 to 2001.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between adherence to the MIND diet and the odds of general and central obesity among adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between the MIND diet score and odds of general or abdominal obesity in the overall population, though a modest initial association in women disappeared after adjusting for confounders.
population_specificity: 6724 adults (mean age 36.8 years) from the SEPAHAN study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between trait mindfulness and physical activity, and whether exercise positive well-being and exercise psychological distress mediate this relationship.
results_summary: Trait mindfulness, exercise positive well-being, and physical activity were positively correlated, while psychological distress was negatively correlated with these variables. Both cross-sectional and longitudinal analyses showed that exercise positive well-being and psychological distress mediated the relationship between trait mindfulness and physical activity.
population_specificity: Young adults (mean age ~19 years, 53-55% male)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness practices, along with physical activity and mind-body therapies, in reducing anxiety, depression, and stress among university students.
results_summary: Mindfulness interventions, along with other methods, significantly reduced anxiety, depression, and stress in 89% of the reviewed studies, with positive effects observed across various intervention types and durations.
population_specificity: University students aged 18-25 without severe mental health conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of an 8-week mindfulness training program on cognitive flexibility and social-emotional skills in elementary school students.
results_summary: The study found that students in the mindfulness group showed significant improvements in cognitive flexibility and end-of-year social-emotional learning grades, but not in teacher-reported social-emotional competence.
population_specificity: 292 5th-grade students from 21 classrooms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of an evidence-based mindfulness intervention on perceived stress, burnout, resilience, and work engagement in nursing professionals.
results_summary: Significant reductions in burnout and perceived stress, along with significant increases in resilience and work engagement, were observed among nursing professionals after the mindfulness intervention. Nursing professionals showed a 10% higher reduction in burnout compared to other participants.
population_specificity: Healthcare workers, including Registered Nurses, Advanced Practice Nurses, physicians, social workers, pharmacists, chaplains, therapists, patient care assistants, and non-clinical staff.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of an 8-week mindfulness and compassion program (MCP-C) for improving psychological well-being in cancer patients and their relatives.
results_summary: The program significantly reduced mean scores on the GHQ-12 and HADS subscales (p < 0.01), with qualitative feedback highlighting benefits like improved health-related decision-making, emotional support, and daily life enhancements.
population_specificity: Adult cancer patients and their relatives.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of group and individual mindfulness-based cognitive behavioral therapy (MBCT) on the happiness of postmenopausal women.
results_summary: Both group and individual MBCT significantly increased happiness scores across all components, with no significant difference between the two methods. The improvements were sustained one month after the intervention.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 50-64, 1-10 years post-menopause, with low happiness scores (less than 40-42 on the Happiness Scale).
effective_dosage: 8 sessions of MBCT counseling (group or individual).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of 4 weeks of access to mindfulness meditation (MM) audio recordings on fatigue impact in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Participants assigned to MM reported significantly greater reductions in fatigue impact, sleep disturbance, and depressive symptom severity compared to the control group, with improvements maintained for up to 28 weeks and no serious adverse events.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS) and fatigue (n=333).
effective_dosage: Access to mindfulness meditation audio recordings (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: 4 weeks of access, with follow-up assessments at 16 and 28 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to co-develop a digital mindfulness-based intervention (MY-ENDO) for women with endometriosis and evaluate their experiences and attitudes toward the program.
results_summary: Participants found the digital MY-ENDO intervention positive, particularly valuing its disease-specific focus and patient collaboration. Key themes included knowledge and management of endometriosis, with motivation and alliance also playing crucial roles.
population_specificity: Women with self-reported symptomatic endometriosis.
study_duration: First four sessions of the intervention (duration per session not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore implementation considerations for online mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) from the perspectives of people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS), care partners, clinicians, and MBI instructors.
results_summary: The study identified four key themes: structuring mindfulness for PwMS, enhancing clinician awareness to improve access, validating mindfulness experiences through group composition and instructor interactions, and sustaining engagement with tailored resources. PwMS valued flexibility and clinician guidance in MBIs, which extended benefits beyond their diagnosis.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS), care partners, MS clinicians, and MBI instructors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mindfulness mediates the relationship between fear of COVID-19 and depression in isolated patients.
results_summary: Mindfulness was found to partially mediate the relationship between fear of COVID-19 and depression, accounting for 32.3% of the total effect. Significant correlations were observed between mindfulness, fear, and depression.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients undergoing at-home treatment.
study_duration: Survey conducted from February to April 2022 (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of caregiver-shared decision-making in family nutritional support combined with mindfulness-based behavioral therapy on malnutrition risk and mood states in patients with gastrointestinal tumors.
results_summary: The integrated approach significantly improved nutritional indicators (body mass index, serum albumin, transferrin), mood states (all seven dimensions of the Profile of Mood States), and reduced malnutrition risk (Nutrition Risk Screening 2002) and mindfulness scores (Mindful Attention Awareness Scale). Compliance and satisfaction rates were also higher in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Patients with gastrointestinal tumors (n = 118) treated at Jiangnan University Affiliated Hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) on glycaemic control and mental health in individuals diagnosed with diabetes.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that MBIs significantly reduced %HbA1c levels and depression scores at follow-up (12-20 weeks), suggesting improved glycaemic control and mental health in diabetic patients.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore changes in quantitative sensory testing measures and the Central Sensitisation Inventory in participants with chronic pain following a mindfulness and physical activity intervention compared to an online self-management guide.
results_summary: The combined mindfulness and exercise intervention was not superior to the self-management guide in terms of changes in pain sensitivity measures or central sensitisation scores. High baseline pain facilitation and central sensitisation were noted, but no significant post-intervention improvements were observed.
population_specificity: Participants with chronic pain (n=33 at baseline, n=22 post-intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mHealth-delivered Mindfulness-Based Interventions (MBIs) in improving perinatal psychological outcomes, including stress, anxiety, and depression.
results_summary: mHealth MBIs showed promise in reducing stress, anxiety, and depressive symptoms during pregnancy and postpartum, but engagement was affected by intervention complexity, technical issues, and user interface challenges. Dropouts were common due to time constraints and technical difficulties.
population_specificity: Perinatal individuals (pregnant and postpartum women)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relevance of Mindfulness-Based Programs, particularly MBCT, in higher education to enhance student flourishing by addressing distractibility and superficial engagement.
results_summary: The study synthesized interdisciplinary perspectives to propose integrating mindfulness into higher education, suggesting it could foster academic excellence and human flourishing by improving attention and engagement.
population_specificity: Higher education students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate depressive rumination, perseverative thinking, mindfulness skills, and self-compassion as potential moderators and mediators of MBCT's effectiveness in reducing depressive symptoms and functional impairment in patients with major depressive disorder.
results_summary: MBCT plus treatment as usual (TAU) was more effective than TAU alone in reducing depressive symptoms and functional impairment, with medium and small effect sizes, respectively. Higher baseline rumination and perseverative thinking, and lower self-compassion, moderated MBCT's effects, but no mediators were identified.
population_specificity: Patients with persistent or recurrent major depressive disorder (MDD), including those with or without a current depressive episode.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of the Mindfulness-Based Health Promotion (MBHP) program on quality of life and well-being in older adults compared to an active control group.
results_summary: The MBHP group showed improvements in stress, anxiety, intrinsic religiosity, and sleep quality compared to the active control group, though no significant QOL improvements were observed. Qualitative findings indicated enhanced perceptions of social support, self-awareness, self-care, and sleep quality in the MBHP group.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess patients' willingness to pay (WTP) and preferences for mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) among individuals with chronic low back pain in Hong Kong's public healthcare sector.
results_summary: Patients exhibited low WTP for MBIs (mean HK$258.75±508.11), with higher pain scores, income, education, and belief in MBIs associated with greater WTP. Preferences favored lower-cost MBIs with better pain relief, improved daily function, and face-to-face delivery.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic low back pain in Hong Kong public hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between dispositional mindfulness and anger/aggression, as well as the effects of mindfulness-based interventions on reducing anger and aggression.
results_summary: The study found small-to-medium inverse relationships between dispositional mindfulness and anger/aggression, and medium effects of mindfulness-based interventions in reducing anger and aggression compared to control groups. Effect sizes were largest in Asia and equivalent across diverse populations.
population_specificity: Diverse populations including clinical, forensic, healthy adults, medical, and students.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy for Children (MBCT-C) in reducing anxiety, depression, and Internet addiction (IA) in adolescents with IA.
results_summary: The study proposes a framework for a clinical trial but does not report results yet; it outlines the methodology for assessing MBCT-C's effectiveness through pre- and post-intervention measures and a three-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Iranian adolescents (Persian ethnicity; males and females; 12 to 15 years) diagnosed with Internet addiction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether mindfulness mediates the relationship between impulsive sensation seeking and readiness for change in individuals with substance use disorders.
results_summary: The study found a significant positive correlation between mindfulness and readiness for change, and a significant negative correlation between impulsive sensation seeking and readiness for change. Mindfulness partially mediated the relationship between impulsive sensation seeking and readiness for change, suggesting its potential to enhance recovery.
population_specificity: 200 clients with substance use disorders

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of mindfulness on aberrant salience and attentional processes, as well as its potential benefits for stress management and well-being.
results_summary: Mindfulness training increased mindful attention and decentering while reducing aberrant salience, particularly heightened emotionality. Participants reported improved stress management and integration of mindfulness practices into daily life.
population_specificity: 21 participants in a pilot study (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: 8-week Mindfulness-Based Health Promotion (MBHP) course (specific session frequency/duration not detailed).
study_duration: 8 weeks, with follow-up at 3 months post-course.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a VR-enhanced mindfulness and yoga intervention in treating postpartum depression and anxiety in women affected by long COVID, while also examining physiological stress markers and cognitive control mechanisms.
results_summary: The VR-enhanced intervention group showed significant improvements in depression and anxiety symptoms, with greater effects than traditional in-person sessions or no intervention. These improvements were strongly correlated with reduced salivary cortisol levels and enhanced cognitive control.
population_specificity: Postpartum women affected by long COVID (n=111).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the transdiagnostic efficacy of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) in reducing depressive symptoms across various psychiatric disorders.
results_summary: The study found that MBIs, including MBCT, ACT, and DBT, were efficacious in treating depressive symptoms across multiple psychiatric diagnoses, with significant effect sizes compared to active controls.
population_specificity: Clinical samples aged 18-65 from 12 different diagnostic categories.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how an 8-week Mindfulness-Based Intervention (MBI) affected the multifaceted self and mental health outcomes in individuals with depression and anxiety disorders.
results_summary: Participants showed improvements in trait mindfulness, anxiety, depression, and self-compassion, with reduced self-negativity and a more positive view of others, though their self-view remained relatively negative compared to others.
population_specificity: 24 individuals with depression and anxiety disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze workplace mental health, including mindfulness, depression, and job stress, among physical therapists in Korea during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: Mindfulness was negatively correlated with stress and depression, showing higher levels among participants with graduate degrees compared to undergraduates. The study found that musculoskeletal physical therapists exhibited higher job stress indexes.
population_specificity: 280 physical therapists in Korea

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effectiveness of a mindfulness-based cancer recovery program (MBCR) combined with an end-of-life demands card game (ELDCG) in alleviating death anxiety, anxiety, depression, and stress in patients with advanced lung cancer.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly lower scores in death anxiety, anxiety, depression, and stress compared to the control group after the 6-week program. The MBCR appeared to offer strategies for managing stress and improving emotional coping.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced lung cancer in China.
effective_dosage: Not specified (MBCR program duration was 5 weeks, following the ELDCG in the first week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of mindfulness-integrated cognitive behavior therapy (MICBT) on depression, anxiety, stress, and sleep quality in women with breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that MICBT significantly reduced depression, anxiety, and stress scores and improved sleep quality in women with breast cancer, with statistically significant improvements observed post-intervention and at follow-up.
population_specificity: Women with breast cancer (30 participants, divided into intervention and control groups).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but follow-up was conducted at two months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how mindful self-compassion therapy can be applied to nurse self-care to improve their physical and mental well-being.
results_summary: The study found that mindful self-compassion therapy effectively reduces occupational and compassion fatigue in nurses, enhances mindfulness, self-compassion, and resilience, and promotes body-mind well-being through practices like breathing exercises and self-compassionate language.
population_specificity: Clinical nurses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether executive function subcomponents (inhibition, updating, shifting) are impaired in individuals with Internet Gaming Disorder (IGD) and examine the effectiveness of a brief mindfulness intervention on these functions.
results_summary: The study anticipates that a 7-day mindfulness intervention will improve executive function in IGD individuals, with outcomes measured via EEG, behavioral metrics, physiological indices, and self-reports. The abstract suggests potential benefits but does not yet report specific results.
population_specificity: 82 individuals diagnosed with IGD and 40 non-addicted gamers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between childhood maltreatment and social mindfulness, examining potential mediators (self-compassion) and moderators (shyness and hostile attribution bias).
results_summary: Childhood maltreatment negatively predicted social mindfulness, mediated by self-compassion. Shyness and hostile attribution bias independently and interactively moderated this effect, reducing the negative impact of maltreatment at higher levels.
population_specificity: 611 undergraduates

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if vibration-augmented breath-focused mindfulness (VABF) could improve respiratory regulation and emotional outcomes in trauma-exposed adults with elevated dissociation.
results_summary: VABF decreased respiration variability (RV) across visits, while other interventions increased RV. RV was positively associated with anxiety and anger ratings, suggesting VABF may improve regulatory processes in this population.
population_specificity: 128 trauma-exposed adults (mean age 30.21 years) with elevated dissociation.
study_duration: Not specified (participants completed at least 50% of intervention visits)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an online mindfulness-based intervention (MBI) to reduce anxiety before a first-time screening colonoscopy among average-risk patients.
results_summary: The study found that both patients and medical staff reported pre-procedural anxiety before a first-time screening colonoscopy, and stakeholder-engaged strategies were essential for developing a feasible and acceptable intervention. The MBI is being tested in a pilot randomized controlled trial to assess feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary efficacy.
population_specificity: Average-risk patients undergoing a first-time screening colonoscopy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a mindfulness-based contextual cognitive defusion training (M-bCCDT) program on perceived stress and other health outcomes in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The M-bCCDT program significantly reduced perceived stress and improved memory function, psychomotor speed, and mindfulness awareness, with benefits sustained for 20 weeks. Individual-level analysis showed statistically and clinically significant improvements in perceived stress and secondary outcomes, though global cognitive function did not improve.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
effective_dosage: Weekly 60-minute sessions for 8 weeks, followed by 12 weeks of unsupervised practice.
study_duration: 20 weeks (8 weeks of intervention, 12 weeks of follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether different breathing patterns (slow vs. normal) during mindfulness meditation differentially affect plasma amyloid beta (Aβ) levels, relevant to Alzheimer's disease risk.
results_summary: One week of daily mindfulness with slow breathing decreased plasma Aβ levels, while normal breathing increased them. The control group showed no changes.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract does not detail participant demographics).
effective_dosage: Daily mindfulness practice (duration and specifics not detailed beyond breathing patterns).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a telehealth mindfulness intervention (MINDful TIME) in reducing internalizing symptoms (e.g., depression, anxiety) in autistic adolescents and improving mindfulness, well-being, and relationship functioning in their caregivers.
results_summary: The study found statistically and clinically significant reductions in parent-reported depression symptoms in autistic adolescents, with female adolescents also showing significant reductions in anxiety symptoms. Parents reported increased mindfulness, well-being, and improved adolescent-parent relationship functioning.
population_specificity: Autistic adolescents (ages 13-18) and their caregivers.
effective_dosage: Eight weekly group meetings and regular use of a commercially available mindfulness meditation app (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore participant perspectives of a virtual mindfulness-based group medical visit for people with chronic low back pain, particularly focusing on historically marginalized communities.
results_summary: The study found that participants' experiences varied significantly, influenced by their external environment (comfort, social demands, sharing personal spaces) and their ability to navigate the virtual platform (ease, struggle, support levels). Mindfulness principles helped participants manage virtual participation amid home challenges.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic low back pain, predominantly women (69.5%) and including a significant proportion of Black or African American participants (45.8%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the weekly changes and long-term effects of Mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) on trait mindfulness and psychological symptoms in young adults with adverse childhood experiences (ACE).
results_summary: The study found that MBIs led to significant increases in trait mindfulness and reductions in psychological symptoms, with most effects lasting up to 12 months without refresher courses. Increases in mindfulness scores predicted reductions in stress and symptom measures, particularly in the MBI group.
population_specificity: Young adults aged 21-35 with adverse childhood experiences (ACE).
study_duration: 8 weeks of intervention, with follow-ups at 6, 12, and 18 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of the eBEfree program, an app-based intervention combining mindfulness, psycho-education, self-compassion, and Acceptance and Commitment Therapy, in reducing binge-eating symptoms.
results_summary: The eBEfree program significantly reduced binge-eating symptomatology, decreased body mass index and depression symptoms, and improved self-criticism and mindfulness dimensions. Over 80% of participants rated the program as positive and helpful.
population_specificity: Individuals with recurrent elevated binge-eating symptoms and higher body weight.
study_duration: 12 weeks (initial assessment to end-of-treatment), with a 26-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify EEG correlates of Mindfulness-based treatment for chronic pain and assess its potential for efficacy evaluation and patient selection.
results_summary: The study found that pain-related evoked potentials and baseline theta power correlate with Mindfulness-based treatment outcomes, suggesting EEG may help predict treatment efficacy and patient suitability. However, the limited number of studies and variability in results indicate the need for further research.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs) on sleep quality in cancer patients and explore moderators influencing these effects.
results_summary: MBIs showed a moderate improvement in sleep quality among cancer patients (g = 0.598, p < .001), with funding and timing of outcome measures identified as moderators. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Cancer patients, predominantly male (14 studies), mean age 53.70 years (SD = 6.52).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and effectiveness of a modified mindfulness training program in reducing antenatal depression and perceived stress among expectant mothers with a male child preference in Pakistan.
results_summary: The study found that the modified mindfulness training significantly reduced antenatal depression and perceived stress scores from pre-intervention to post-intervention, with minor but significant declines at follow-up. The program was deemed culturally suitable and contextually relevant for the target population.
population_specificity: Expectant mothers with antenatal depression, perceived stress, and a male child preference in Karachi, Pakistan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the Mindfulness-based Social-Emotional Growth (MSEG) program in enhancing the mental health of elementary school students in South Korea.
results_summary: The MSEG program significantly improved emotional regulation across all grades, with lower-grade students showing reduced anxiety and depression and upper-grade students demonstrating enhanced resilience compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Elementary school students in Gyeonggi-do, South Korea (grades 1-6).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively and qualitatively assess the neuropsychological (executive functioning and social cognition) and EEG effects of mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs).
results_summary: The study found that MBIs show strong correlations with cognitive and electrophysiological improvements, particularly in executive functions and frontal alpha-beta asymmetry, though research on social cognition is limited. While most treatment effects were positive (58%), the average outcome did not significantly differ from zero, indicating methodological variations and confounding factors.
population_specificity: Individuals with psychological and psychiatric conditions (e.g., depression, anxiety) in developing countries, though broader implications are discussed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of mindfulness-based interventions as an adjunct treatment for body dysmorphic disorder (BDD) by examining existing clinical evidence.
results_summary: The study suggests mindfulness-based interventions show promise in improving symptoms of BDD, particularly in reducing body image disturbances, anxiety, repetitive thoughts, and cognitive rigidity, based on their efficacy in similar conditions like eating disorders and obsessive-compulsive disorder.
population_specificity: Individuals with body dysmorphic disorder (BDD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and theoretically justify MBCT-G, a mindfulness-based cognitive therapy program integrated with gaming, to address self-prescription disorders like IGD by promoting positive coping strategies.
results_summary: The study proposed MBCT-G as a novel approach to treating IGD by focusing on response and reward processes through gaming, offering an alternative to traditional treatments that target the disorder directly. It integrates mindfulness-based cognitive therapy with cognitive behavioral models to alleviate psychological distress.
population_specificity: Individuals with internet gaming disorder (IGD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) and job stress coping training in reducing job burnout among employees.
results_summary: Both MBCT and job stress coping training were equally effective in reducing employee burnout, with the effects persisting at follow-up. The results were statistically significant (P ≤ 0.05).
population_specificity: Employees from the technical departments of Tam Kar Company in Isfahan with middle to high stress levels.
effective_dosage: Eight 90-minute sessions of MBCT for experimental group 1; ten 90-minute sessions of job stress coping training for experimental group 2.
study_duration: 8 sessions for MBCT, 10 sessions for job stress coping training (each session 90 minutes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of Mindfulness-Based Therapy (MBT) in improving sexual desire/arousal and distress in women with Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder (SIAD) compared to a waitlist control.
results_summary: MBT significantly improved primary outcomes (sexual desire/arousal and distress) with large effect sizes (d > 0.90 for desire/arousal, d < -0.62 for distress), maintained at follow-up. MBT also showed slightly greater improvements in sexual satisfaction compared to CBT, with no effect on sexual dissatisfaction and large improvements in overall sexual function (d = 1.20-1.23).
population_specificity: Women with Sexual Interest/Arousal Disorder (SIAD)
effective_dosage: 8 modules with a recommended completion time of 8-12 weeks

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a one-week mindfulness-based intervention on resilience, social behavior, and motor skills in preschool-aged children.
results_summary: The mindfulness group showed significant improvements in motor skills and social behavior but no significant effect on resilience compared to the physical activity and control groups.
population_specificity: 45 preschool-aged children (4-5 years old) from the same preschool.
